ratings.comment: Professor McFarland is a very entertaining lecturer, and his content is incredibly interesting to anyone with any interest in biology. My only complaints would be that this course is graded almost entirely off of 3 difficult tests and a few essays (of which McFarland's was the hardest, as there were a lot of questions to answer in too few words).

McFarland was by far my favorite professor for Anthro 100. He expected a lot but was straightforward in his lectures so his expectations were clear. He was always in a great mood and somehow got me excited about the difference between apse and monkeys. You don't need to do the readings. I got a B+ because I had a hard time remembering dates.

Not only does McFarland know what he's talking about, he's always in a good mood and gives entertaining and concise lectures. The class I took was very test heavy and I didn't finish with the grade I would've liked, however I still feel like I learned a ton from his class and I would love to have him again.

I took professor McFarland for Anthro 105 and I absolutely loved going to class. He's such a good lecturer and is very passionate about what he's talking about. The only downside to the class is that there are only 140 points for the semester so it's easy to not do well. I would 100% take another class of his in the future.

McFarland is an awesome professor; his lectures are interesting and his powerpoint slides are very clear. But, there's only two exams for the entire semester, both of which are very detailed. The class isn't out of many points, so it can be difficult to get a good grade.

Some questions in the tests are super specific which makes it really difficult. Also, you can only get a total of 12 points off on every assignment combined, so it makes it very difficult to get an A. Richard lectures well and gives you information you need to know. Be careful about talking during class because he frequently calls people out.

He is a very clear lecturer with amazingly concise and clear lecture slides. Also his accent is cool. Loved his lectures, didn't get a chance to study for the exam very much but still got an A because I just naturally retained info from his lectures.
Super organized slides, very concise with information.

Biweekly quizzes, every point in the course is worth a percentage point. Mainly based off quizzes, no exams, and two projects. One a group project and one you get to go to the zoo and look at monkeys. He is such an amazing lecturer and is really passionate about what he does, which makes it even better for students.

One of my absolute favorite professors. Very concise with his ideas, some of the most organized lecture slides I've ever seen, but he doesn't post them online so you need to go to class. Lectures and the book go well together, the book gives details on topics he discusses. Made 1/3rd of this class very interesting.

McFarland is very knowledgeable and the course material is (personally) very interesting. There are no midterms or finals for the class. The quizzes are only based off lecture material, can be challenging , and every point counts.  If you have time to study or are good at memorizing, you'll do fine.

This class was easy. The only thing that makes it difficult is that the quizzes are very specific, luckily the quizzes are often so there is not a lot of material on any of the quizzes which makes it much easier. Professor McFarland and all of the TAs were very nice but lectures and labs were very boring.

Richard's class has 6 quizzes and 3 papers that make up your grade. Every point you lose is a point off of your grade, beware! If you're good at memorizing, you'll get an AB or above. The textbook really isn't necessary since everything on the quizzes is from lecture.

Professor McFarland is very knowledgable on the subject, but he is pretty strict and rigid in terms of his expectations of the students. His quizzes are fairly difficult, as they feature random facts from lecture - study the slides! He offers extra credit if you answer questions in lecture. The grading scale has changed, so it's harder to get an A.

Professor McFarland is exceptionally knowledgable. Just beware if taking Anthro 105 that your grade rests on 6, 12 question MC quizzes. The quizzes ask super specific questions, and since the class is only graded out of 100 points, you have no room to bomb a quiz.

super great guy w a good accent but the way the class was graded made it more difficult. if you get a few points off on the quizzes you're pretty much down to an AB. the book was completely useless, don't buy it. All the readings are only recommended anyway. if it weren't for the tricky quizzes this would be a great class bc of interesting material

McFarland was a great professor. Super cool and chill guy. The labs for this class were fun which I wasn't expecting as I don't like bio. Each point is a percentage of your grade. If you mess up one of the 12 pt quizzes your grade will tank even if you do well on the rest. It sucks but make sure you study the right material

Professor McFarland was an extremely clear, concise, and interesting lecturer. He was very passionate in anthropology (especially non-human primates). I really enjoyed coming to class, and he had a pretty sweet British accent. The class was very easy, with grades coming from six 12-point quizzes, a few papers and labs, and no exams.

While Dr. McFarland is a very good professor, the grading style that has been set for Anthro 105 is absolutely horrible. Every quiz question is worth a percentage of your grade. The quizzes along with one small worksheet and two short essays make up a full 100 points for the class. The content is interesting but difficult to keep up with.

The lectures can get pretty dull.  You don't have to attend them to get an A though.  Also, the textbook isn't really essential if you want to save some money.  Labs are interesting and interactive.   This is a very easy, introductory course for Anthro.   Would recommend to meet science requirements.
My favorite professor I've had so far. His lectures were interesting; he is knowledgeable and easy to listen to. The class overall is very straight-forward, and I would recommend it to everybody.

His lectures were so boring, but the class was the easiest one I've taken at UW. The labs were fun and really easy and the TAs were all amazing! Enthusiastic, helpful, funny. No exams, just ten question/multiple choice quizzes. Easy class, boring professor.  It's really frustrating that all the good things I had to say were about the TAs.

Found his class very interesting, he's very fair, and has a wicked accent. There aren't any midterms or a final which is a plus. The class was based on 100 points but as long as you paid attention and did the assigned work you'll pass.
Never attended any lectures except for the last few to get some extra credit points! SUPER EASY CLASS and great professor.

This class was so great, It was a really easy way to get a biology credit. The whole class is out of 100 points split between 7 quizzes and 4 labs. You don't need the book at all as long as you pay attention in lecture.

Great class to take for biology credit as well as broadening your horizons. I learned a lot about our evolution, as well as primate sociology and biology. Biweekly quizzes for 10 points which  make up 70 points of your grade, and 30 points from labs, totaling 100 points (1 point  1%). Very easy if you take notes and study before the quizzes.

I took this class in hopes to get an easy biological science credit, and I was not disappointed. The class does not have an tests, just quizzes and the labs are easy. I would definitely take this if you are looking for 3 easy bio credits.

Super easy and interesting class. Quizzes every other week are a 10/10 so long as you skim the material. There is an attendance sheet passed around, but I'm not sure if he takes into consideration for grades. I had a 2pm 50 min lecture so no reason for me to skip

He's very intelligent and experience especially for his age. He got me excited about primates which was cool. Bi-weekly quizzes are easy if you even kind of did the reading. No exams at all. Labs are interesting and lab reports are super easy and short.

Richard is a great lecturer. Even talking about primates, he knows how to make it interesting. The quizzes are difficult, so make sure you are studying for them. The labs are not too hard. The grading criteria is clear, so it makes it real easy to know where you stand in the class. His accent is hot.

No big exams, just weekly quizzes. Quizzes aren't super easy, so you need to study a bit. I recommend reading the textbook for the quizzes. Lab work is fun and you need to do 4 short lab write-ups. Hot accent.

The class has no exams, and instead are based only off four group projects (which you basically do in section) and seven quizzes, with all the material presented in lecture.  Attendance isn't required for lecture, but he's a fascinating lecturer, and you'll want to go.
